transcripts.speaker: Patrick
transcripts.text: Thanks everyone for joining. This is our kickoff meeting for the Acme Corp website redesign project. I want to make sure we're all aligned on scope, timeline, and deliverables. Jennifer, can you start by giving us an overview of what Acme is looking for?

transcripts.speaker: Jennifer Walsh
transcripts.text: Absolutely. So Acme Corp wants a complete redesign of their marketing website. The main goals are improving conversion rates, mobile responsiveness, and updating the brand to feel more modern. They've given us a budget of $75,000 and want to launch by end of Q1. Their CEO is particularly focused on the homepage and pricing page experiences.

transcripts.speaker: Tom Chen
transcripts.text: That timeline is tight but doable. For the technical side, are we rebuilding from scratch or working with their existing CMS? Also, do they need any integrations - CRM, analytics, that sort of thing?

transcripts.speaker: Jennifer Walsh
transcripts.text: They want to move to a new CMS - they're currently on WordPress but want something more modern. I'd recommend we propose Webflow or a headless CMS. For integrations, definitely HubSpot for their CRM and they mentioned wanting better analytics than what they have now.

transcripts.speaker: Rachel Green
transcripts.text: For the design side, do we have brand guidelines to work from? And how many unique page templates are we looking at? That'll really affect my timeline for the mockups.

transcripts.speaker: Jennifer Walsh
transcripts.text: They have basic brand guidelines but they're open to refreshing the visual identity. I'd say about 8 to 10 unique templates - homepage, about, pricing, product pages, blog, contact, careers, and a few landing page variants.

transcripts.speaker: Patrick
transcripts.text: Okay let's make some decisions. First, CMS - I think Webflow makes sense given the timeline and their team's technical level. Tom, do you agree? Second, we need to decide on the project phases.

transcripts.speaker: Tom Chen
transcripts.text: Webflow works for me. It'll speed up development significantly. For phases, I'd suggest: Phase 1 is discovery and design - 3 weeks. Phase 2 is development of core pages - 4 weeks. Phase 3 is remaining pages and integrations - 3 weeks. Phase 4 is testing and launch - 2 weeks.

transcripts.speaker: Rachel Green
transcripts.text: That works for design. I can have initial homepage concepts ready within the first week and a half. Full mockups for all templates by end of week 3. I'll need the brand refresh decision made by end of this week though.

transcripts.speaker: Patrick
transcripts.text: Perfect. Let's lock that in. Decision made - we're going with Webflow and the 12-week timeline Tom proposed. Jennifer, can you draft the SOW and send it to Acme by Friday? Tom, start setting up the Webflow workspace. Rachel, schedule a brand workshop with their team for early next week.

transcripts.speaker: Jennifer Walsh
transcripts.text: I'll have the SOW ready by Thursday for internal review, then send Friday. I'll also set up the shared Notion workspace for project documentation.

transcripts.speaker: Tom Chen
transcripts.text: Workspace will be ready by tomorrow. I'll also document the technical requirements and share with the team.

transcripts.speaker: Rachel Green
transcripts.text: I'll reach out to their marketing lead today to schedule the brand workshop. Aiming for Tuesday or Wednesday.

transcripts.speaker: Patrick
transcripts.text: Excellent. This is a great start. Let's plan to sync again next Monday to review the SOW feedback and brand workshop outcomes. Thanks everyone!
